poem:
Umbrellas  

Tension unfurls  
beneath the spreading ribs—  
a canopy of awkwardness.  
In each gust,  
the stubborn arc  
betrays its promised cover.  
Raindrops laugh,  
whisper escape,  
as we clutch at failing spokes.  
What pact made  
between man and storm,  
breathes calamity  
in cloth and metal?  
Let the rain—  
let it fall unbroken,  
untainted by pretension.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why do I hate umbrellas? How long have you got? | Adrian Chiles Umbrellas, I don’t like them. Don’t get on with them, never have. When my aunt in Zagreb was absorbed in some crime drama on the television, she would say it was “as tense as an umbrella”. The English translation doesn’t work, but if I may turn it around, I would like to explain why umbrellas make me tense. There are so many". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Why do I hate umbrellas? How long have you got? | Adrian Chiles Umbrellas, I don’t like them. Don’t get on with them, never have. When my aunt in Zagreb was absorbed in some crime drama on the television, she would say it was “as tense as an umbrella”. The English translation doesn’t work, but if I may turn it around, I would like to explain why umbrellas make me tense. There are so many
